PACIFIC TRAIL
Seek for AR markets on the trail

The Costa Rica Pacific Slope Pacific Slope Trail Network is a vision to link forests and rural communities along Costa Rica’s Pacific Slope. It begins in the famous Monteverde conservation region, and will encompass a network of trail systems, huts, conservation properties, ecological agriculture initiatives, alternative energy, and wastewater treatment and water conservation projects.
You are here

Description: Head, neck and lower parts cream-white color, conspicuous mask connected through the neck. Chaplet finely sprinkled with black, chocolate-brown back and wings, tan-rufo remiges, at the base with dark stripes.
Behavior: This hawk is seen on a perch for long periods with its head slightly crouched.
Diet: Feeds almost exclusively on snakes, both terrestrial and arboreal, including large and poisonous, although more broadly hunts the harmless.

Description: Length between 80 and 130 cm (more than half belongs to the tail), the color of its coat is grayish brown, for the most part, has white spots above and below the eyes as well as on the cheeks. It has a long nose, pointed and flexible, its front legs are shorter than the rear and its tail remains erect.

Behavior: Mostly diurnal, at night, it usually rests in the tree canopy far from the reach of predators. The males usually live in a solitary way marking their territory and are among them, while the people live in groups of between 4 to 20 individuals next to the young.
Diet: These animals are omnivores, but they feed mainly on insects. They can also eat fruits and some small vertebrates.

Description: The Tailed Kite, is “An elegant and uniquely shaped raptor, with long and narrow wings and a very forked tail” the colors of this bird are black and white, with blue-gray shades on the top.

Behavior: Regarding its behavior this is usually seen in flight rising and sliding while twisting its tail. The flapping is deep and fluid. It is found in a diversity of wooded habitats with preference for humid habitats near rivers and ponds.
Diet: According to Lemke, it is known that the Tailed Kite makes its prey adult insects, wasp larvae, small amphibians and reptiles.
Description: Opaque black, short tail, heavy flight with short glides and strong wings. White patches at the base of primary remiges.

Behavior: Generally associated with open and semi-open areas, being more numerous around the cities, mainly in landfills or sanitary landfills or sometimes on the edges of roads where garbage is thrown.
Diet: It feeds on carcasses of animals that die from different infectious diseases, but also feeds on eggs and can even kill or injure young and defenseless animals.
Description: Mostly black coat with yellowish cream head, chest and shoulders. The face is pink. The tail is prehensile.
Behavior: This monkey can live in bands from a few to about 30 individuals. It has been recorded that white-faced monkeys can cover an area that varies between 30 and 160 hectares.
Diet: Frugivore, Insectivore, Carnivore, Granivore / Seedbed.
Description: Large rodent, with orange brown fur. Pink bare ears, with rounded ends. The blackish legs, in the front have 4 fingers and the hind legs 3 fingers, with nails.
Behavior: They are diurnal. They form couples or loners. They take refuge in holes dug in the ground, under fallen logs or cracks between stones.
Diet: They eat plant matter (fruits, seeds), although they can eat small animals.
Information kiosk: Here you can find information about the trail route and you can also see the augmented reality markers.
Signaling: These points shows information about the name of the trail you are in and a small map of the route.
